courseTitle: Applied Chemistry and Physics for Nurse Anesthetists
courseDescription: This course is a review of the principles of organic chemistry, biochemistry, and physics. It is designed as a foundation for the students' understanding of pharmacology, physiology, and the anesthesia gas machine. This course will also provide an introduction to the chemical structure-activity relationships, metabolism and mechanism of action of selected agents.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding mechanism of action of selected agents
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying principles of organic chemistry, biochemistry, and physics to solve problems
Analyzing the effects of selected agents on metabolism and their mechanism of action

courseDescription: This course focuses on normal physiological functioning of body systems building on undergraduate anatomy and physiology to further examine structure and function focusing on cellular, subcellular, genetic and biochemical processes.   The goal is to provide an in-depth understanding of the function and regulation of body systems to maintain homeostasis. Learners will integrate physiologic concepts for the basis for critical thinking and decision making when assessing patients with multi-system failure. Learners are provided with essential knowledge of human health and disease across the lifespan necessary for advanced nursing practice. This course consists of four hours of lecture/discussion/in-class clinical module work per week.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of cellular, subcellular, genetic and biochemical processes
Knowledge of human health and disease
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in medical decision making
Analyzing and understanding the function and regulation of body systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Participation and engagement in lecture/discussion/in-class clinical module work
Ability to maintain homeostasis in body systems

courseTitle: Applied Principles of Anesthesia Practice I
courseDescription: This course integrates scientific concepts with basic principles of anesthesia practice and prepares the student for their new role in the safe and effective delivery of anesthesia. Emphasis is on vital anesthesia monitoring and delivery systems. Airway management and general anesthesia techniques will also be discussed. Simulation is incorporated into the learning process to reinforce principles introduced in class.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integrating scientific concepts with anesthesia principles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Preparation for new role in anesthesia delivery

courseTitle: Applied Principles of Anesthesia Practice II
courseDescription: This course formulates a basic level of cognitive, affective, and psychomotor expertise for the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative anesthesia periods. Students will analyze and apply basic physiological principles in preparation for the anesthesia management of patients undergoing complex surgical procedures. Human Simulation is incorporated into the learning process to reinforce principles introduced in class.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative anesthesia periods

courseTitle: Applied Principles of Anesthesia Practice III
courseDescription: This course is the third course in a series of three and is intended to further the foundation for safe and effective delivery of anesthesia. It is designed to prepare the student for the decision making necessary for the complex issues of anesthesia in clinical practice. Students will apply knowledge of pathophysiological conditions to formulate safe plans of care for patients undergoing complex surgical procedures. Human Simulation is incorporated into the learning process to reinforce principles introduced in class.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making for complex anesthesia issues
Adapting anesthesia plans to patient's pathophysiological conditions

courseTitle: Advanced Pharmacology for Nurse Anesthesia Practice
courseDescription: This is a course in advanced anesthesia pharmacotherapeutics that builds on prior knowledge of drug classification, actions, interactions and adverse drug reactions. The major focus of the course is synthesizing principles learned in Advanced Pharmacology for Nursing Practice and applying them to anesthetic pharmaceuticals. Emphasis is placed on the critical thinking process used to choose and prescribe drugs in the management of anesthetic. Core concepts include applied pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, volatile agent delivery systems, theories of anesthetic action and the interactions between patient medication and anesthetic agents. This course consists of three hours of lecture/discussion/in-class clinical module work per week.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of volatile agent delivery systems
Knowledge of theories of anesthetic action
Understanding of drug classification, actions, and interactions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of patient medication and anesthetic agents interactions
Synthesizing principles learned in Advanced Pharmacology for Nursing Practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing in-class clinical module work

courseTitle: Evidence Based Seminar for Anesthesia Practice
courseDescription: This course helps prepare advanced practice nurses with an opportunity to assess clinical and scientific evidence through appraisal of the literature. The course explores the philosophical underpinnings for nursing knowledge and evidence in nursing practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of nursing knowledge and evidence
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions around nursing knowledge and evidence

courseTitle: Evidenced-Based Seminar for Anesthesia Practice I
courseDescription: This course is the first in a series of five seminar courses that helps prepare advanced practice nurses with an opportunity to assess clinical and scientific evidence through appraisal of the literature. The course explores the philosophical underpinnings for nursing knowledge and evidence in nursing practice.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on nursing knowledge and evidence

courseTitle: Evidenced-Based Seminar for Anesthesia Practice II
courseDescription: This course is the second in a series of five seminar courses that helps prepare advanced practice nurses with an opportunity to assess clinical and scientific evidence through appraisal of the literature. The course is designed to build on the understanding gained in NURA 761 and to expand the advanced practice nursing student's understanding of research methods, design, and statistics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of clinical and scientific evidence

courseDescription: Independent study in nurse anesthesia under the guidance of a faculty.

courseTitle: Advanced Physiology and Pathophysiology for Nurse Anesthesia I
courseDescription: This course addresses normal and abnormal physiological functioning of body systems building on undergraduate anatomy and physiology. Structure and functions of the systems will be examined at the cellular, subcellular, genetic, and biochemical level. The goal is to provide an in-depth understanding of the dysfunction of body systems in a diseased state as well as comprehension of the normal function to maintain homeostasis.  Systems to be addressed include:  cellular and molecular physiology, immune system, nervous system, skeletal muscle system, and the cardiovascular system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human anatomy and physiology
Knowledge of cellular, subcellular, genetic, and biochemical structures
Understanding of normal and abnormal physiological functioning of body systems
Knowledge of immune system, nervous system, skeletal muscle system, and cardiovascular system
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex physiological functions
Ability to communicate the state of a patient's body system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of how to maintain homeostasis
Ability to diagnose and understand diseases at a cellular level
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage and prioritize patient care
Ability to lead and educate others in understanding complex physiological functions

courseTitle: Advanced Physiology and Pathophysiology for Nurse Anesthesia II
courseDescription: This course addresses normal and abnormal physiological functioning of body systems building on undergraduate anatomy and physiology. Structure and functions of the systems will be examined at the cellular, subcellular, genetic, and biochemical level.  The goal is to provide an in-depth understanding of the dysfunction of body systems in a diseased state as well as comprehension of the normal function to maintain homeostasis.  Systems to be addressed include:  respiratory system, digestive/hepatic system, endocrine system, and neoplasia mechanisms and treatments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human anatomy and physiology
Knowledge of molecular and biochemical processes
Insight into respiratory, digestive/hepatic, and endocrine systems
Expertise in identifying and understanding neoplasia mechanisms and treatments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex physiological processes in layman's terms
Capacity to communicate patient conditions effectively
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding the dysfunction of body systems in a diseased state
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Prioritizing and managing patient care based on level of system dysfunction
Leading healthcare teams in managing patient conditions

courseDescription: A study of the unique goals, distinctive content, and special problems of health/anesthesia care and education in this country. Includes such areas as management, organization, legal aspects, professional adjustments, ethics, psychology, and history.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of legal aspects in health/anesthesia care
Awareness of the history and evolution of anesthesia
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional adjustments in health/anesthesia care environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing special problems in health/anesthesia care
Analysis of psychological aspects in anesthesia
Critical evaluation of management strategies in anesthesia care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of anesthesia care and education
Leadership in anesthesia care and education

courseDescription: This course formulates a basic level of cognitive, affective, and psychomotor expertise for the preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative anesthesia periods. Students will analyze and apply basic physiological principles in preparation for the anesthesia management of patients undergoing complex surgical procedures. Human simulation is incorporated into the learning process to reinforce principles introduced in class.
Technical and Digital Skills: Management of patients undergoing complex surgical procedures
Use of human simulation in learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Patient communication before, during, and after anesthesia
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative stages

courseDescription: This course is the third course in a series of three and is intended to further the foundation for safe and effective delivery of anesthesia. It is designed to prepare the student for the decision making necessary for the complex issues of anesthesia in clinical practice. Students will apply knowledge of pathophysiological conditions to formulate safe plans of care for patients undergoing complex surgical procedures. Human Simulation is incorporated into the learning process to reinforce principles introduced in class.
Technical and Digital Skills: Formulating safe care plans for complex surgical procedures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a clinical setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading care plan formulation and implementation

courseDescription: This course is the fourth in an increasingly more complex eight-course series intended to accompany NURA 842. It is designed to review basic sciences and equipment, instrumentation and technology related to clinical practice.

This course is the fifth in an increasingly more complex eight-course series intended to accompany NURA 843. It is designed to review basic sciences and equipment, instrumentation and technology related to clinical practice. This course also incorporates preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative care of patients.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in using clinical instrumentation and technology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team communication in a clinical setting

courseDescription: This course is the sixth in an increasingly more complex eight-course series intended to accompany NURA 844. This course is designed to review anesthesia concepts and begin the preparation to take the National Certification Exam.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing study materials for successful certification

courseDescription: This course is the seventh in an increasingly more complex eight-course series intended to accompany NURA 845. This course is designed to review anesthesia concepts and continue the preparation to take the National Certification Exam
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in complex medical scenarios
Adapting anesthesia techniques to diverse patient needs

courseDescription: This course is the final in an increasingly more complex eight-course series intended to accompany NURA 846. This course is designed to review anesthesia concepts and examine student readiness of the National Certification Exam.
Technical and Digital Skills: Readiness for the National Certification Exam
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying areas of improvement for National Certification Exam readiness

courseTitle: Nurse Anesthesia Practicum: Orientation for Clinical Anesthesia
courseDescription: This introductory-level course is designed to integrate didactic knowledge with basic practical application. The student will apply knowledge concerning preoperative assessment, care plan development, induction sequence, basic airway management, function and usage of anesthesia equipment, pharmacology dosing and mathematics for anesthesia. Course content is based on the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Function and usage of anesthesia equipment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adjusting anesthesia plans based on patient condition

courseDescription: This introductory-level course is designed to integrate didactic knowledge with basic practical application to the art and science of nurse anesthesia. It designed to cultivate the novice student nurse anesthetist in selected clinical settings under direct supervision of qualified clinical preceptors. The student will be immersed in the anesthesia clinical environment for this course. Course content is based on the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and adhering to the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Implementing appropriate anesthesia techniques based on patient needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adhering to the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials

courseDescription: This clinical course is the third in an increasingly more complex six-course series and continues the integration of didactic knowledge and practical application to the art and science of nurse anesthesia. It is designed to cultivate the competent student nurse anesthetist in a variety of clinical settings under the guidance of qualified clinical preceptors. The student will be immersed in the anesthesia clinical environment for this course. Course content is based on the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of didactic knowledge and practical application
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively in a clinical setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying nurse anesthesia practice standards in real-world scenarios
Analyzing clinical settings and applying appropriate anesthesia techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing patient care in a variety of clinical settings
Leading in a clinical anesthesia environment

courseDescription: This clinical course is the fourth in an increasingly more complex six-course series and continues the integration of didactic knowledge and practical application to the art and science of nurse anesthesia. It is designed to cultivate the proficient student nurse anesthetist in a variety of clinical settings under the guidance of qualified clinical preceptors. The student will be immersed in the anesthesia clinical environment for this course. Course content is based on the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of didactic knowledge in nurse anesthesia
Adherence to Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice
Understanding and application of DNP Essentials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a clinical environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and resolution of anesthesia-related issues

courseDescription: This clinical course is the fifth of six in an increasingly more complex six-course series, and continues the integration of didactic knowledge and practical application to the art and science of nurse anesthesia. It is designed to cultivate the proficient student nurse anesthetist in a variety of clinical settings in collaboration with qualified clinical preceptors. The student will be immersed in the anesthesia clinical environment for this course. Course content is based on the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of didactic knowledge to practical application
Compliance with American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a clinical environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing patient conditions in various clinical settings
Applying clinical solutions in a complex, real-world environment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of patient care in a variety of clinical settings

courseDescription: This clinical course is the final in an increasingly more complex six-course series and continues the integration of didactic knowledge and practical application to the art and science of nurse anesthesia. It is designed to cultivate the proficient student nurse anesthetist in a variety of clinical settings in collaboration with qualified clinical preceptors. The student will be immersed in the anesthesia clinical environment for this course. Course content is based on the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of didactic knowledge and practical application
Understanding and application of anesthesia clinical environment
Knowledge of American Association of Nurse Anesthetists Standards for Nurse Anesthesia Practice and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing DNP Essentials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Verbal and non-verbal communication in clinical settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to adapt and apply anesthesia techniques in a variety of clinical settings
Analytical skills to evaluate patient conditions and apply appropriate anesthesia
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of patient care in a variety of clinical settings
Leadership in anesthesia practice within a clinical team

courseTitle: Evidenced-Based Seminar for Anesthesia Practice III
courseDescription: This course is the third in a series of five seminar courses designed to enhance the nurse anesthesia student's understanding of research methods, design and analysis. A journal club format is used to evaluate anesthesia care for optimum outcomes using published research studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design and analysis of research studies
Evaluation of anesthesia care using published studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participation in a journal club format
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of research studies for optimum outcomes

courseTitle: Evidenced-Based Seminar for Anesthesia Practice IV
courseDescription: This course is the fourth in a series of five seminar courses designed to enhance the nurse anesthesia student's understanding of research methods, design and analysis. A journal club format is used to evaluate anesthesia care for optimum outcomes using published research studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of anesthesia care using research studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and argumentation in a journal club format
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying research to optimize anesthesia outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and leading a journal club discussion
Application of research findings to clinical practice

courseTitle: Evidenced Based Seminar for Anesthesia Practice V
courseDescription: This course is the fifth in a series of five seminar courses designed to enhance the nurse anesthesia student's understanding of research methods, design and analysis. A journal club format is used to evaluate anesthesia care for optimum outcomes using published research studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design and analysis of research studies
Evaluation of anesthesia care using published research studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participation in a journal club format
Discussion and critique of research studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of research studies for optimum anesthesia outcomes
Critical evaluation of research methods and design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions in a journal club format
Organizing and interpreting research data for practical application

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
